item.description:
Once Upon a Time in Anatolia by Nuri Bilge Ceylan (Turkey, 2011, 150 min.). Winner of the 2011 Cannes Film Festival grand prize, the film tell the story of how an overnight search for a missing person leads to quiet ruminations on the consequences of adultery, the suffering of children and the limited hope for the future they represent, and the recessive role of women in Turkish society. “Visually, it’s as gorgeous a film as Ceylan has made . . .,” (Justin Chang, Variety). In Turkish with English subtitles. A reception at the SMFA follows screening.

Come early and enjoy live music and check out Taste, our café and wine bar in the Linde Family Wing for Contemporary Art.

 New York Times Critics Pick

Rotten Tomatoes: 88%

AV Club:  A-

"Once Upon A Time In Anatolia, from supremely gifted Turkish writer-director Nuri Bilge Ceylan (Distant,Climates), never gets past the body—in fact, the search for it takes longer than some movies last. The epic-length drawing-out of such a basic component of the police procedural might sound agonizing, but it gives the search and its aftermath tremendous dramatic weight for the men on the hunt. The body means different things for each of them, and Ceylan’s mesmerizing existential drama takes its time establishing the players and bringing their inner lives into focus. 

I would strongly encourage you to reserve your tickets early.  Nothing worse than arriving at the MFA only to find the film sold out:  Tickets 

There may be a reception following the film, or we may go to a nearby eatery to discuss.  in any event, I'll send an email before the event making sure everyone knows where to find us and how best to proceed on a weeknight film.  

Winner of the 2011 Cannes Film Festival Grand Prize, this is one film in 2012 I've waited a long time for a showing in Boston.

 

See you at the movie,

John
